story:
My name is Nate Augspurger. For those of you who don't know me, I’m twenty-three years old and grew up in Minneapolis, MN. I come from a hardworking, middle class family and have one older brother. I've been playing sports my entire life and started playing rugby when I was eleven years old. I continued to play throughout high school, which is when I really fell in love with the game.

In 2008, I was lucky enough to gain admission to the University of Minnesota (Twin Cities) and was blessed to be able to continue to play rugby at an elite level. In my first year of college, I decided that I would like to pursue playing rugby professionally. Additionally, I realized that there was not a doubt in my mind that I want to represent my country.

I put in a lot of hard work throughout college to advance my rugby career, while also pursuing my Bachelor of Arts Degree in Sociology. Each summer I competed at the men’s club level along with attending invitational elite rugby camps (Serevi). My Men’s club was fortunate to compete in two national championship tournaments and these events were instrumental in establishing my name as an elite player on the national scene. I was extremely proud to graduate with my degree in the spring of 2012, proving to myself that I could achieve greatness off the field as well as on.

The following summer I showed enough potential to get called into a Men’s USA Rugby Sevens camp as they prepared for the beginning of their season and in September, at the USA 7’s camp, I got the opportunity to show my dedication, talent, hard work, and passion for the game. I was humbled to receive a developmental contract that would keep me around for the season of 2012-2013. 

I was then selected to go on tour and compete with the best rugby players in the world on the World Series Sevens Rugby Circuit in Dubai, UAE and Port Elizabeth, South Africa where I represented the USA for the first time in my career. In one of life's many twists, I was soon sidelined when I  broke my fibula while playing for the developmental USA team in Las Vegas. Once again I was able to demonstrate the attributes I bring to the team on and off the field. Only two months and two weeks after my surgery I was running at full speed and back practicing with the team.

Sevens Rugby was recently inducted into the Olympics and will be hosted for the first time at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. My dream is to be there and play for the USA. I don’t just want to represent my country; I am determined to be a centerpiece of the team and help lead our country to a gold medal!  I have many goals I intend to accomplish over the next few seasons with USA team. I am, and will remain, a student of the game, always trying to gain experience and boost my rugby I.Q. and I will never get complacent. I’m driven by the ultimate goal of performing in front of the entire world, not just the international rugby community, and making my country proud. I’m very ambitious, passionate, and confident about achieving this goal, but I could use a little help. 

 

I can only contribute so much to my rugby goals while in Minneapolis. I need to be in Southern California at the Chula Vista Olympic Training Center training full time with my other USA teammates. The good news is that I was awarded a contract with the USA 7’s team for the 2013-14 season. However, due to cutbacks to the program and my lack of tenure with the team, the contract is only partial at this time. This is why I’m soliciting monetary donations.

I’m looking to raise about 3,000 dollars to continue my journey. Below please find a summary of my financial needs over and above my partial contract:

• Monthly Rent

• Living Expenses (i.e. Food, Bills, Cleaning Supplies, etc.)

• Bicycle for transportation 

• Emergencies, Illnesses

• Plane Ticket Home for the holiday 

 

Anything that you can give will mean the world to me!

I understand that not everyone will be able to help with a donation, but I want you to know that I very much appreciate you taking the time out of your busy schedule to read my story and I ask that you share this link with your friends, family, coworkers, acquaintances, and anyone else who you think might want to help me live my dream

 

Please also see below for great article about me by Megan Ryan of the Minnesota Daily!

http://www.mndaily.com/news/campus/2013/04/02/transition-nate-augspurger

story:
TURN OUTRAGE INTO ACTION

Let's put our energy into fighting sexual violence & supporting survivors. 

Glorying sexual violence and giving advice on how to commit a sexual assault have no place in our society, online or off.  Over the past month, 732 people have made contributions to fund a “how-to” manual endorsing sexual assault, providing instructions like these:

“Don’t ask for permission. Be dominant. Force her to rebuff your advances.”

“Pull out your coc* and put her hand on it. Remember, she is letting you do this because you have established yourself as a LEADER. Don’t ask for permission, GRAB HER HAND, and put it right on your dic*.”

  • Let’s show the world that there are more people who support survivors of sexual violence than there are people who advocate for violence.

  • Let’s invest in programs and initiatives that change the way Americans think about sexual violence.

  • Let’s ensure that survivors get the help they deserve through the National Sexual Assault Hotline.

Every 2 minutes someone in the U.S. is sexually assaulted. Since 1994, RAINN has helped over 1.8 million people take the first steps towards recovery through the National Sexual Assault Hotline (800.656.HOPE & online.rainn.org). 

Make your voice heard! Contribute to this campaign to show that we will not tolerate sexual violence!

 

As seen in:          

About RAINN

RAINN (Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network) is the nation's largest anti-sexual violence organization and was named one of "America's 100 Best Charities" by Worth magazine. RAINN created and operates the National Sexual Assault Hotline (800.656.HOPE and online.rainn.org) in partnership with more than 1,100 local rape crisis centers across the country. The hotline has helped more than 1.8 million people affected by sexual violence since 1994. RAINN also carries out programs to prevent sexual violence, help victims and ensure that rapists are brought to justice.

The Online Hotline provides live, secure, anonymous crisis support for victims of sexual violence, their friends, and families. As the nation's first web-based secure hotline service, the Online Hotline uses a unique platform that's as intuitive as instant messaging — ideal for users who are more comfortable communicating online than over the phone. The Online Hotline is free of charge and is available 24 hours per day, 7 days per week! 

In addition to helping survivors, RAINN holds an annual day of action, RAINN Day, to raise awareness and educate college students about sexual assault on college campuses. A grassroots program that's designed to empower students to educate their peers about risk reduction and recovery resources available on campus, RAINN Day reaches thousands of students each year.


If you or someone you know has been sexually assaulted, it's never too late to get help. Please call 800-656-HOPE (4673) or visit online.rainn.org.

story:
OK I NEED HELP FOLKS.. MY GF CHRISSY CARPENTER HAS BREAST CANCER, AND I TOOK HER TO CHEMO WEDNESDAY, ONLY TO HAVE HER ADMITTED DUE TO BLOOD CLOTS IN HER LEG & PULMINARY EMBOLISMS IN HER CHEST!? HER HUSBAND LOST HIS JOB & IS IN THE HOSPITAL HIMSELF AS HE IS HAVING A COMPLETE NERVOUS BREAKDOWN SINCE HER DIAGNOSIS! THE STRESS ALONE OF THAT COMBINED WITH NO $ COMING IN, AND THEIR MEDICAL INSURANCE BEING CANCELLED THIS FRIDAY, IS NOT HELPING HER GET ANY HEALTHIER!? THE FAMILIES Verizon FiOS GOT SHUT OFF, HER CENTRAL AIR IS BROKEN, THEY HAVE ZERO MONEY COMING IN & NEXT THE CAR WILL BE REPO'D AND I'M WORKING ON GETTING A MEDICAL HOLD PUT ON HER PECO & Aqua America, BUT EVENTUALLY THE MORTGAGE CO./HOUSE, GROCERIES ETC.... I CAN'T HANDLE ALL THE PHONE CALLS THAT NEED TO BE MADE MYSELF & SHE'S THE KIND OF PERSON WHO DOESN'T LIKE ASKING FOR HELP BUT AT THIS POINT I WILL NOT LET HER PRIDE KILL HER!?

FIRST & FOREMOST, SHE NEEDS AN AIR CONDITIONER BIG ENOUGH TO COOL HER DOWNSTAIRS OR AN HVAC PERSON TO COME LOOK AT & FIX HER CENTRAL AIR UNIT FOR FREE? (HOPEFULLY HV THAT COVERED ALREADY) 2ND, I NEED SOMEONE OR A FEW PPL TO HELP MAKE PHONE CALLS, AND SOMEONE TO HELP ORGANIZE A BENEFIT TO RAISE MONEY TO HELP HER PAY BILLS?? IN THE MEANTIME, A FRIEND INTRODUCED ME TO THIS DONATION SITE SO IF YOU FEEL LED TO DONATE FINANCIALLY HERE'S A GREAT SAFE WAY TO CONTRIBUTE!! =) 

Dawn Cariola-brown Michelle Bechara Carboni, Justine Hodges Anne Bradley DiVito, ELLE BROOKS & I ARE DOING THE BEST WE CAN & WILL BE HELPING EACHOTHER CARE FOR HER 7YR OLD, GIANA, WHILE BOTH HER PARENTS ARE IN THE HOSPITAL BUT WE ALL HV LARGE FAMILIES OF OUR OWN SO ANYONE WILLING TO HELP OUT W/ TIME, GROCERIES, MONEY, PRAYER, TRANSPORTATION OR WHATEVER YOU CAN DO!? PLS INBOX ME ON FB OR CALL ME 484-688-6349 ASAP!? THANK YOU IN ADVANCE FROM THE BOTTOM OF OUR HEARTS!!!

story:
Short Summary

The Dry Dock provides a sober alternative to the community. A friendly, open and supportive place where fellowship is the cornerstone of recovery, an envirnment where an open heart, mind and understanding of recovery and it's pitfalls is openly shared, where living in the principles of a twelve step program is encouraged.

I am Rich Figlewski, founder and President of the Dry Dock. I am also a recovering alchoholic and addict.

In January of 2010 two friends in recovery died. One drank himself to death and was found in his apartment 4 days later. The other wrote a note to his mother, went in the bathroom and shot up an overdose of heroin. The lonliness and pain weree just too much for them. This story repeats itself over and over, daily at times, in the recovery community. I left my job in Febuary 2010, took may severance and retirement and started the Dry Dock. I believe that by having a safe place for people saves lives. We survive on donations and the kindness of others. There are no salaries.

Your contribution will help keep us open. Your contribution will help save lives.

Remember, "if you are not careful, you might just help somebody."

What We Need & What You Get

Your funding contribution will go directly to our overhead for the next 10 months. We will use the comtributions to pay our rent, $900.00 a month, and a portion of the utilities. We expect to be able to cover the other expenses with the donations and support we normaly receive.

Also, we need to expand our peer mentoring and outreach programs to get the word out that there is a safe place to go among people who care and many who have "been there."


We are hoping to increase our donor base over the next few months as well. The community is begining to understand the work we do. I partner with the local soup kitchen, the town social services group, the school superintendant's  office, the Rotary Club, the mayors council on substance abuse, the local substance abuse council, the local heath department and the Spanish community center.

We are a 501[c]3 corporation so all donations are tax deductible.

For every donation of $25  or more we will provide a dry dock baseball cap.

For every donation of $50  or more we will provide a dry dock t-shirt.

All contributions we recieve will be used towards the stated purpose, to help pay our overhead and expand community outreach.

The Impact

We provide whatever help we can, rides to hospitals, to detox facilities, help in placing folks in treatment, food when you are hungry, a place to sit and read, to talk with others about where you are that day. To share with whatever we have with families struggling, kids who are losing their childhood much to fast, and to parents watching their children slowly die in front of them.

We try to live in a place where an open heart, mind and arms is the routine, not the exception. Kindness, Love and Understanding, is all that matters.

This is a disease, not a life choice. The gift of sobriety requires constant vigilance and support. There are few places for people to gather in a social place without alchohol or drugs being around. Music, open mics, cookouts, dances, motorcycle rides, cards, meditation, reiki and a little diner serving breakfast, lunch and dinner is what we provide. We also have 12 step meetings daily, about 20 a week.

We provide what we can at little or no cost. We have recently been accepted as a United Way agency. We are a legitimate business providing what we can. The need surpasses the funds available.

When the cold weather comes more people will be coming in to eat and stay warm. We have been succesful helping some of the homeless get and stay sober for the past two winters. We need to be able to provide more as this population is growing.
 
The precription drug abuse problem is epidemic in this area. This leads to more deaths and heroin addictions. especially among the young people on our community.
 
We cannot save everyone. In fact a power greater than us is at work, we just act as a conduit. Please join us on this journey. The love shown to others is the redemption of ouselves.

Other Ways You Can Help

I am fully aware how tough the times are today.
Money is tight and we recognize that not all can contribute financially. Your support by sharing this campaign with those you know would be great.
 
More than anything please keep us in your thoughts and prayers.

Peace & Blessings
 
Rich Figlewski, Executive Director
203-626-5560

story:
We made it - we hit our target!


Hi. We are Nick and Flóra, and together we make up Findacure: The Fundamental Diseases Partnership. We have managed to secure matched funding from a very generous donor, so EVERY dollar you donate will be DOUBLED up! Find out more about our team below. 

What are fundamental diseases?

Fundamental diseases are extreme and rare genetic disorders, which offer a unique opportunity to better understand other diseases, including many common conditions. 

Take the drug statins for example. Statins were originally developed as a result of research into the mechanisms of an ultra-rare disease called familial hypercholesterolemia. Statins are now the most common treatment for high cholesterol, prescribed to millions of people.

Another great example is the ultra-rare disease alkaptonuria. Latest research into alkaptonuria is revealing new insights into the causes of osteoarthritis, which could lead to the development of new treatments. 

Additionally, research into a group of rare neurological diseases called neuroacanthocytosis is helping to understand Parkinson's and Huntington's diseases.

Why do fundamental disease patients need support?

There are hundreds of millions of people worldwide with these diseases, but they are mainly ignored due to their rarity.

As a result, patients are often overlooked, isolated, and neglected due to the rarity of their conditions. Many go through life without ever meeting another person with the same condition. If patient groups are set up, they usually only offer basic support and do not have the time to expand the organisation.

However, for fundamental diseases, the patient groups are a vital partner. Research from Rare Disease UK shows that patient groups act as a vital source of information and support for patients. They are also the first port of call for pharmaceutical companies and academics preparing clinical trials for possible treatments. 

Yet there is no support structure to help fundamental disease patients to set up their own formalised patient groups. Many do not have the knowledge to run these organisations and do not know how to get involved in research.

How we want to help:

We aim to fill this unmet need by developing a support system to help fundamental disease patient groups to grow and professionalise their work. 

We propose setting up an easily accessible online toolkit and series of free workshops covering pertinent issues for these patient groups, ranging from how to manage a patient organisation to working with academia to help advance research into their disease.

We have already had one patient workshop in January, on the topic of accessing funding as a small patient group. It was a big success. We had over 40 patient advocates attending and four speakers; two from successfully-funded patient groups and two from fundraising consultancies.

The toolkit will comprise of a website which will display vital and useful information about important issues for fundamental disease patients and patient groups. This information will be complemented by a series of short videos that summarise technical topics into coherent, concise explanations.

We are asking for $25,000 to run a series workshops throughout 2014 and to set up our online toolkit.

So please donate now. EVERY dollar you donate will be MATCHED by our generous funding partner, Myrovlytis Trust.


How your money will be spent:


Head over to the gallery to see a more detailed break-down of how the money will be spent.


Other ways you can help:

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools on this page to tweet, like, G+, or email our campaign to your friends!
  • Talk about the Fundamental Diseases. It’s time to care crowdfunding campaign on your blog or Facebook page.
  • Create your own video about how you are affected by fundamental diseases. 


The Perks:

Donate $25 and you will receive one of these lovely handwritten postcards and your name on our website as a thank you. You will get to choose which design.


Donate $50 and you will receive one of these fantastic wristbands, a handwritten postcard and your name on our website as a thank you.


Donate $75 and get a lovely Findacure t-shirt, along with your name on our website as a thank you.


NEW PERK: Donate $100 and get a Findacure ‘Time to Care’ clock, along with your name on our website as a thank you.


Donate $100 and get a personalised tune, produced by Nick on his electronic music software. Here's an example:

 Sample tune.


Donate $150 and get a copy of Nick’s book, along with a wristband and your

name on our website as a thank you.


The Team:

To prove to you how dedicated we are to this campaign, five of the team members (Nick, Flóra, John, Julie, and Andy) will be running ten 10km runs EACH over the coming 45 days. Keep an eye on the updates to see how we are doing.

are extreme and rare genetic disorders, which offer a unique opportunity to better
understand other diseases, including many common conditions. Take the drug statins for example. Statins were originally developed as a result of research into the mechanisms of an ultra-rare disease called familial hypercholesterolemia. Statins are now the most common treatment for high cholesterol, prescribed to millions of people.Another great example is the ultra-rare disease alkaptonuria. Latest research into alkaptonuria is revealing new insights into the causes of osteoarthritis, which could lead to the development of new treatments. Additionally, research into a group of rare neurological diseases called neuroacanthocytosis is helping to understand Parkinson's and Huntington's diseases.Why do fundamental disease patients need support?There are hundreds of millions of people worldwide with
these diseases, but they are mainly ignored due to their rarity.
As a result, patients are often overlooked, isolated, and
neglected due to the rarity of their conditions. Many go through life without
ever meeting another person with the same condition. If patient groups are set
up, they usually only offer basic support and do not have the time to expand
the organisation. 
However, for fundamental diseases, the patient groups are a
vital partner. Research from Rare Disease UK shows that patient groups act as a
vital source of information and support for patients. They are also the first port of call for
pharmaceutical companies and academics preparing clinical trials for possible
treatments. Yet there is no support structure to help fundamental disease
patients to set up their own formalised patient groups. Many do not have the knowledge to run these
organisations and do not know how to get involved in research.How we want to help:We aim to fill this unmet need by developing a support
system to help fundamental disease patient groups to grow and professionalise
their work. We propose setting up an easily accessible online toolkit and
series of free workshops covering pertinent issues for these patient groups,
ranging from how to manage a patient organisation to working with academia to
help advance research into their disease.
We have already had one patient workshop in January, on the topic of
accessing funding as a small patient group. It was a
big success. We had over 40 patient advocates attending and four speakers; two from
successfully-funded patient groups and two from fundraising consultancies. 
The toolkit will comprise of a website which will display
vital and useful information about important issues for fundamental disease
patients and patient groups. This information will be complemented by a series
of short videos that summarise technical topics into coherent, concise
explanations.
We are asking for $25,000 to run a series workshops
throughout 2014 and to set up our online toolkit. 
So please donate now. EVERY dollar you donate will be MATCHED by our generous funding partner, Myrovlytis Trust.
How your money will
be spent:

Head over to the gallery to see a more detailed break-down of how the money will be spent.
Other ways you can
help:


Use the Indiegogo share tools on this page to
tweet, like, G+, or email our campaign to your friends!


Talk about the Fundamental Diseases. It’s time to care crowdfunding campaign on
your blog or Facebook page.


Create your own video about how you are affected by fundamental diseases. 



The Perks:Donate $25 and you will receive one of these lovely
handwritten postcards and your name on our website as a thank you. You will get to choose which design.
Donate $50 and you will receive one of these fantastic
wristbands, a handwritten postcard and your name on our website as a thank you.
Donate $75 and get a lovely Findacure t-shirt, along with
your name on our website as a thank you.NEW PERK: Donate $100 and get a Findacure ‘Time to Care’ clock, along with your name on our website as a thank you.Donate $100 and get a personalised tune, produced by Nick on his electronic music software. Here's an example: Sample tune.Donate $150 and get a copy of Nick’s book, along with a wristband
and your name on our website as a thank you.The Team:To prove to you how dedicated we are to this campaign, five of the team members (Nick, Flóra, John, Julie, and Andy) will be running ten 10km runs EACH over the coming 45 days. Keep an eye on the updates to see how we are doing.

story:
Aidan was diagnosed with Ulcerative Colitis in 2011, a condition which affects his daily life. He has managed it reasonably well, but the last 12 months have been really tough. 

Although he was insured by a major insurance company, they have used technicalities to refuse reimbursement claims of over SGD$15,000 in medical bills, paid between February 2013 and January 2014. Taking legal action would be stressful, time-consuming, and unrealistic. 

We can't offer much in return for any donations, apart from a big thank you and the feeling that you've help a friend and fellow musician out. No donation amount is too small.

We'll be throwing a fundraiser event on Sun 23rd February, 3pm-midnight at Blu Jaz Cafe, Singapore, where there'll be DJs, live music jams and a good vibe. Even if you can't donate, please help spread the word by sharing both the Indiegogo page, and the FB event: https://www.facebook.com/events/722222587796455/?ref_dashboard_filter=upcoming

Just so you know - our good friends at Matteblacc are helping us by receiving the donations on the Indiegogo page through their Paypal account.

For those who do not know Aidan personally, here's a bit of background:

Since arriving in Singapore in 1999, Aidan has poured his heart and soul into the music scene. Co-founder of Wicked Aura Batucada, he managed the band for 5 years and performed with them around the world. 3 years ago, DJ Shellsuit and Aidan setup Sideshow, and made it their mission to help promote non-mainstream music and art in Singapore. The company prides itself on creating new opportunities for deserving artists, most of whom are Singaporean.  Their events have become some of Singapore's most loved by families, music lovers, and artists.

More information on Ulcerative Colitis - http://www.ccfa.org/what-are-crohns-and-colitis/what-is-ulcerative-colitis/

Ulcerative Colitis in layman terms (as related by former England rugby captain Lewis Moody) - http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-26070749

story:
Ask and it is given, so now we're asking for your participation in our healthy co-creation!

We believe that recovery from disease is happening everyday in our world around us. So while Ria's recovery is happening everyday, from now and through the next 3months we're asking you to be our co-contributors and co-creators on this healthy journey.

When it comes to healing, it's good to have options.  Options for fresh food, options to seek other healing modalities and the option to be with Ria in Kingston during her stay at KGH. We've been very blessed by friends offering their vehicles so I may be there with Ria at KGH as much as possible during this time.  With your contributions we'll have options for Ria's treatments that are not covered in our medical system as the need is required.  With the medical options limited to surgery, radiation or chemotherapy and Ria's doctors recommending all 3 for her, yet they only estimate a 15-20% cure rate for Ria with this specific cancer using all 3 of their options.  With her 6 hours of surgery just completed, it took her 12 hours in the recovery room and an epidural for her pain. She said of the experience in surgery, that is was as good as it could be, with such wonderful staff caring for her.  The doctors want to begin radiation & chemotherapy together, starting this week, only 3-4 days after her surgery.  Her surgery entailed dissecting a small piece of her small bowel that was constricted by the tumour, lifting her small bowel around the tumour, holding it in place with some netting that dissolves in 3 months, so it's out of the way in preparation for the radiation treatment. They would like to use 2 forms of radiation treatment on Ria, the external radiation beam, across her abdomen with a wide beam, as well they are also recommending Brachytherapy.  They are also recommending chemotherapy and radiation treatment together for a period of 5-7 weeks.  Now, I don't know about you, but that seems like something that if I had another option to try, I may just take it!

When contributing to this campaign, you're contributing more than money.  You're contributing your energy, your thoughts, your inspirations and your desires towards health, light, love & happiness.  It is our heart's focus to share healing with those we love and we so appreciate this co-creation of the heart and allow it's light to shine brightly and far reaching!

Sharing what we love is what we love to do, so bringing some of our favourite recipes together for you in an ebook book of delicious creations.  We've created unique & delicious SeaMint Teas, for your relaxing pleasure.   And of course we offer choices of thalassotherapy for the face or body.  A renewal of body & mind that goes more than skin deep.

story:
Our time is up, and we have raised $19,227.00! Thank you all so much!

Every dollar donated will be matched, which brings the total amount to: $38,454.00

~~~~~

Typhoon Haiyan has destroyed the infrastructure in coastal areas of the Philippines, leaving millions of people displaced, without shelter and access to safe, clean water and sanitation.

The Rotary Club of Fort Lauderdale is raising funds to donate LifeStraw® Personal, LifeStraw® Family, and LifeStraw® Community water filters & purifiers to emergency family shelters in the most disaster affected areas.

How You Can Help

By distributing LifeStraw® water filters & purifiers to shelters and aid stations, we can rapidly provide people with safe, clean water.

We will match your donations up to $23,000, and use the total funds raised of at least $46,000 to purchase LifeStraw® water purifiers for immediate distribution.

With this matching program, the Rotary Club of Fort Lauderdale is hoping to provide more than 250 community shelters and safe spaces for children with safe, clean water. The filters will be delivered directly to our international humanitarian partners who are currently engaged in on-the-ground disaster relief in the Philippines: ShelterBox, Lutheran World Relief (LWR), and Child Fund International. 

The timing is urgent. We need to deliver these purifiers within the next two weeks, so please donate whatever you can.

"Our #1 priority is water...The water is very dirty with E. coli, just dirty sediment and sand, and people are bathing in it," Cogan said. "They're also drinking it, unfortunately, which is making them sick."
 -Judy Colgan with Global Medic, as told to CBC's Chris Brown.


The Impact of LifeStraw®

LifeStraw® Community water purifiers provide high-volume point-of-use water purification with built-in safe water storage to produce clean drinking water for community settings. They prevent waterborne disease such as diarrhoea, typhoid, cholera, worms, and cryptosporidiosis, by removing viruses, bacteria, and protozoan parasites from contaminated water. Each Community purifier is capable of providing more than 100 people with safe drinking water each day.

LifeStraw® Family water purifiers are gravity fed systems that remove viruses, bacteria & protozoa without the use of batteries, chemicals or moving parts. They utilize a long lasting, 0.02 micron hollow fiber membrane filter, which provides 4750 gallons or 18000 liters of water, enough to supply a family of five with purified drinking water for up to three years.

LifeStraw® Personal water filters remove bacteria & protozoa with human suction power. They allow the user to pull water through the filter just like drinking from a straw, making them easy to use, convenient and portable. LifeStraw® Personal filters provide 264 gallons or 1000 liters of water, enough for one year of clean water if used daily.

LifeStraw® water purifiers have been successfully distributed to hundreds of thousands of people in developing countries and crisis affected regions around the world. Haiti, Pakistan, and many countries in Africa have received LifeStraws® since 2005. These purifiers provide an interim solution for water related issues until wells or long-term solutions can be implemented.

The The Rotary Club of Fort Lauderdale is an official partner organization for LifeStraw® donations in developing and crisis affected countries. Our relationship with Vestergaard, the manufacturer of LifeStraw® water filters and purifiers, allows us to purchase and donate large quantities for aid, at factory-direct cost.


The Crisis

Typhoon Haiyan (known as Yolanda in the Philippines) struck last Friday, leaving devastation in its wake. The worst storm to ever hit the Philippines, and one of the strongest storms ever recorded, it has left over 500,000 people homeless and millions without food and clean water. The death toll rises every day, with fears that over 5,000 people may have lost their lives to this tragic event.

Without food, clean water and shelter, the survivors of typhoon Haiyan are struggling to hold on. Currently most of those affected by the typhoon do not have access to safe drinking water, which is critical to survival. The drinking wells and available water sources communities rely on have been damaged and highly contaminated in the aftermath of the typhoon, which will result in the spread of illness and disease if interim solutions are not put in place immediately. The provision of safe, clean water in temporary shelter facilities is an important part of the response effort.


Please help us help the victims of Typhoon Haiyan!

Thank you so much for your support.

Martin Brody,
Rotary Water Projects Chairman
Rotary Club of Ft. Lauderdale, Fl

story:
If you are reading this you probably know someone who knows our friend Mary. You may even know that she has been dealing with health issues. They are quite serious and require ongoing treatment and maintenance to keep her healthy. What you may not know is that due to a series of circumstances outside her control, she has found herself in dire financial straits that are a serious and immediate threat to her health and well being. As people that love and care about her, we've decided to coordinate an emergency fundraising campaign to help her get out of this situation as soon as possible. We are asking you to please give as generously as you can within your means.


Mary was diagnosed with Crohn’s disease in November 2012 and has an especially aggressive case. Managing the disease requires constant treatment to keep her from having acute flare-ups that require emergency hospitalization. Lack of access to funds and therefore treatment has resulted in three hospitalizations in the last three months alone.

Here’s what’s been happening lately. After she was discharged from the hospital in December, Mary found out that her health insurance had been retroactively canceled without notice, due to a series of internal “processing errors.” After a struggle with the insurance company, they finally agreed to reinstate her, but not until she pays them $1,935 for the past due months. During the time without insurance, she has not been able to afford or receive her prescriptions, steroid treatments, and chemotherapy; her condition has taken a turn for the worse. Despite this, she has been working tirelessly (too tirelessly for her own good, health-wise, perhaps, but with no other option) to secure full-time employment but hasn't been successful thus far. Mary is a giving person, but like many of us, when it comes to her own situation she doesn't want to burden her friends.  But, she needs our help so we are asking on her behalf.



We urgently need $5,472 just to cover her past due insurance, prescriptions, housing and treatments. While this will greatly improve her current situation, it will, at best, only put her back where she was before the this domino effect began. The reality is, Mary may need to stop freelancing and focus on regaining her health, so that ultimately she is well enough to secure and maintain full-time employment with benefits. For this reason, our goal is to raise a minimum of $10,000.

We can do this. We just need you to give what you can, whether that is $50 or $5000. No amount is too small, and certainly no amount is too large!


Here are some examples of how your donations can help: 

  • $30 = copay for a regular doctor’s visit

  • $50 = a visit to her GI specialist

  • $300 = one month’s worth of supplements, vitamins, probiotics, and protein powders

  • $515 = one month’s treatment of Remicade, a crucial part of her treatment regimen that is currently missing due to its cost (yes, this is the co-pay with insurance)

  • $1935 = immediate reinstatement of her health insurance

  • $5472 = Mary gets caught up on all outstanding medical bills and living expenses!

  • $10000 = all past due medical bills plus one month of living expenses through February 2014


Want to help beyond supporting this campaign and being a friend to Mary? Wow, you are excellent! Email us privately if you’d like to help with another resource, or if you can specifically help with the following:

  • We are looking for a health advocate based in NYC who can navigate insurance options: Medicare, ACA, Cobra, disability benefits, etc.

  • Naturopathy experts and acupuncturists who operate on a sliding scale fee in NYC.

  • Professional (employment-related) resources

  • New or refurbished-like-new mac laptop

  • If you're interested in donating any "perks" in exchange for donation amounts through our campaign, please get in contact with any of us (see our contact info below) directly. 

The seriousness and urgency of Mary's situation has necessitated us opening this campaign to the public. However, for personal and professional reasons, we still want to do our utmost to preserve Mary’s privacy. Please exercise discretion and good judgment with this information.

Thank you in advance for helping us (or your friend) to help Mary. She is very special to us!





Friends and family of Mary Pryor are uniting to help with medical and living expenses.

We’re encouraging people to give within their means.  That may be $5, $50, $500 or $5000.  All are welcomed! We’ll need donations of all sizes to make our goals. Every donation helps!

Crohn’s disease is an autoimmune condition and, like many illnesses, has very real symptoms that are often not visible to the naked eye. 

Crohn’s is an inflammatory bowel disease that affects the digestive tract and how the body is able to process and absorb nutrients with symptoms that manifest differently in each person. Learn more about it at the Mayo Clinic or at Everyday Health and check out MP’s posts while you’re there!

Mary’s site on living with Crohn’s: http://wheremycrohniesat.tumblr.com

The Affordable Care Act went into effect on Jan. 1, 2014.  We’re exploring all options but the earliest that Mary will be able to change her insurance option is March 1st.

Also, treatments like Remicade and chemotherapy that carry patient copays upwards of $515 place MP in the highest marketplace bracket.  Our first priority is to get her coverage reinstated to cover her past bills and and allow her to resume treatment for the month of February.

We are using Indiegogo because all money donated (minus a small processing fee that the site charges) will go to Mary even if we don’t reach the goal. And when we do reach the goal, Indiegogo will refund a portion of that fee, so that even more of the money goes directly to Mary.

We are using the PayPal option so that your donations will be instantly available for Mary to use in order of most immediate need throughout the duration of the campaign. We'll be posting updates along the way, too! 

If we can get 50 concerned friends to give at least $50 dollars, we can begin to help Mary relieve much of her financial stress. If you are able to give anything at all, please do so by clicking donate.

We’ll need donations of all sizes to make our goals. Every donation helps!Crohn’s disease is an autoimmune condition and, like many illnesses, has very real symptoms that are often not visible to the naked eye. Crohn’s is an inflammatory bowel disease that affects the digestive tract and how the body is able to process and absorb nutrients with symptoms that manifest differently in each person. Learn more about it at the Mayo Clinic or at Everyday Health and check out MP’s posts while you’re there!Mary’s site on living with Crohn’s: http://wheremycrohniesat.tumblr.comThe Affordable Care Act went into effect on Jan. 1, 2014.  We’re exploring all options but the earliest that Mary will be able to change her insurance option is March 1st.Also, treatments like Remicade and chemotherapy that carry patient copays upwards of $515 place MP in the highest marketplace bracket.  Our first priority is to get her coverage reinstated to cover her past bills and and allow her to resume treatment for the month of February.We are using Indiegogo because all money donated (minus a small processing fee that the site charges) will go to Mary even if we don’t reach the goal. And when we do reach the goal, Indiegogo will refund a portion of that fee, so that even more of the money goes directly to Mary.We are using the PayPal option so that your donations will be instantly available for Mary to use in order of most immediate need throughout the duration of the campaign. We'll be posting updates along the way, too! If we can get 50 concerned friends to give at least $50 dollars, we can begin to help Mary relieve much of her financial stress. If you are able to give anything at all, please do so by clicking donate.

story:
I have set this up for my cousin Matt "Cheesburger" Owens. He was in a very serious car accident on the way to work while working on the road in North Dakota a little over a year ago that has left him paralyzed from the waist down. 

Since being in the accident he has went trough physical therapy and was in the hospital for over two months. He has shown a lot of progress but still has a ways to go. He has of course had to come of the road and is no longer able to work as a millwright He has had to move in with his parents and they are having to help take care of him. 

The main reason for this is to get enough money to get him a new wheelchair and other supplies that he needs each day such as catheters, medication, etc. The wheelchair he needs is over $3500. At this time he is using loaner chair that doesn't fit him or his needs. 

Matt "Cheesbuger" is one the hardest working people I know. With him not being able to work on the road and define his craft as a millwright has been a huge blow to him emotional not to mention being paralyzed for the rest of his life. I just would like to thank everyone a head of time for taking the time to even look at this page. If you can't donate the other thing you can do to help is spread the word to others for this cause. 

 

Thanks,

Justin

story:
Our Story

As Bangladesh turned 40 in 2011, Wasfia Nazreen, a rights-activist, writer and development practitioner, ventured out to climb the Seven Summits, the highest mountains in each of the seven continents.


This is the first time a Bangladeshi has taken up such a challenge and she has already reached the top of Aconcagua, the summit of South America on 16th December, Bangladesh's 40th Victory day and Kilimanjaro, the summit of Africa on 2nd October 2011.


Wasfia is headed to Everest, the summit of Asia and the highest mountain of the world next.

The Impact

In the process, Wasfia & friends formed the Bangladesh on Seven Summits Foundation, a pioneering educational institution that aims to train women and adolescent girls of her country in outdoor sports and wilderness activities. The Foundation believes that physical activities and confidence building as such is the first step in breaking the centuries-long gender-based social barriers, where a woman's place is to serve at home only and not encouraged to participate in outdoor sports. Classes plan to start in Fall 2013.

What We Need

Wasfia has been undergoing a serious amount of grueling training, and in order to fund her mountains, has sold of all her material belongings as well as took out a number of personal & bank loans. The money you donate here will be used to help Wasfia pay off those loans first and any/all amount left will be used in the Foundation's work.


"I am fully determined to reach the top of all seven continents and have sacrificed most of the regular things in my life on this mission. I hope you will join me and help me reach my target! The world must listen to Bangladesh, and hear her across the heights of Kilimanjaro to Denali, Aconcagua to Sagarmatha!" - wasfia nazreen

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us make history for Bangladesh! Be part of the movement and join us at https://www.facebook.com/BangladeshOnSevenSummits and don't forget to spread the word!

story:
Think Globally, Cook Locally. 

Kitchen Passports: Trinidad and Tobago invites young cooks and their adult helpers to drop everything and travel to Trinidad and Tobago – right in their own kitchens. Each recipe is a passport to tasty ingredients and yummy dishes enjoyed in Trinidad and Tobago, the second largest nation in the West Indies. Kitchen Passports aims to encourage kids to travel through their taste buds, to create meals and share them with others, and to learn about a culture unfamiliar to them, all while developing their skills as young cooks. 

This project began when my daughter started helping me in the kitchen when she was about 18 months old. She learned what a circle is by stirring batter in a bowl in small and large circles. When my son was old enough, he joined us in the kitchen, squishing, mixing, and cutting ingredients to include in dishes the whole family would eat. As they cook with my husband and I, our children are also learning how to make foods that we grew up eating – for my husband, foods largely from Trinidad and Tobago. 

Kitchen Passports is easy to navigate. The recipes are organized by level of difficulty – 1 island recipes, 2 island recipes, and 3 island recipes. There are 30 recipes in all. Colorful photographs (some shot on location in Trinidad) accompany each recipe. There are also special notes about cooking tips and cultural, social, and other information about Trinidad. Scattered throughout the cookbook are postcards from a young girl growing up in Trinidad. 

Recognizing that there are no children’s cookbooks focusing on Trinidadian cuisine, Kitchen Passports provides young chefs with unique opportunities to create healthy, fun, traditional foods that would otherwise be too difficult for them to make. Inspired by early memories of cooking with my parents as a child, I designed the cookbook to answer these questions: How can we involve kids more in making the food they eat? How can kids become more excited about trying new foods and, through them, experiencing different cultures? How can children develop their literacy skills – reading, social, and cultural literacies – through their kitchen travels? 

I adapted some of the recipes – all of which were tested by young chefs in homes and in classrooms – from traditional recipes provided by my mother-in-law and her mother; both were born and raised in Trinidad. Most of the recipes take ingredients common in Trinidad cuisine – like mangoes and curry – and use them in dishes that allow children to experiment with different spices in a more familiar food context – for instance, putting pineapples in buttermilk pancakes.

Your contribution will help defray the costs of producing and distributing Kitchen Passports. Your contribution will also help us provide funds to Ray of Hope, a nonprofit organization that supports orphanages and children centers in Trinidad and Tobago. A portion of the funds raised through this campaign will help purchase food, books, and supplies for 200 children in Trinidad. 

Contact me at kitchenpassports@gmail.com with questions or comments.

Photographs by Paloma Torres; Trinidad photographs by Crystal D. Furlonge.

story:
Please visit www.jameshowellusa.com.

My name is James Howell and I have been heavily involved in sports since the age of 2. I am 26 years old and a Business Marketing graduate from Angelo State University. Ever since I picked up a football at 2 years old, it has been my lifelong goal to become a professional athlete. I started off playing Pop Warner football and running for a youth track club, in Long Beach, California, at 6 years old. I was never the biggest, tallest, or strongest but I was always known for my speed. My mindset has always been that regardless of my stature, you could never measure my heart or desire to accomplish any goal I set out. I played football and ran track through high school and made it to the California State Track Meet in the hurdles.

Hypoglycemia is a clinic syndrome that results from low blood sugar, that I was diagnosed with my senior year in high school. I was diagnosed with this disorder after an episode, when my sugar level dropped below a stable range, at football practice which caused me to get rushed to the hospital. But I had always been such a healthy kid? Hypoglycemia has been a non-stop concern in my life ever sense, because I always have to be aware of the specific foods I put into my body. Otherwise I will crash into another episode. These episodes do not allow my body to move and make me sleepy; which is dangerous because I can go straight into a coma if I do so. My college coaches were always surprised when they would hear about my situation, because of my work ethic. But the truth is; I do get drained out faster than the average person. 2012 was a season where I didn’t have the college support to keep my healthy life style and doctor guidance to keep my sugar level balanced and stable. This disorder has put me in a category, but I have kept myself out of the class of a quitter. I have overcome obstacle after obstacle and Hypoglycemia Is just another stepping stone in my path towards my goal of being a Track & Field Champion.

After being diagnosed and learning how to control my Hypoglycemia, my achievements in high school, due to my God given abilities and strong work ethic, earned me a scholarship to the University of Akron. There I played football for one year and decided to focus 100% of my energy on becoming a USA and World Track & Field Champion. The first year I stepped onto the NCAA Track I wasn’t the fastest, but by the end of the season I broke the school record, became the MAC Indoor Champion and MAC Outdoor Runner-Up in the 400 meters. After the 2007 season I went through a life changing situation that almost ended my athletic career. After that turning point, I knew I had to fully commit myself to God and my childhood goal, of becoming a professional athlete. So I dedicated my life to that transition, and the end result was another school record at Angelo State and a 3rd place finish in the 2011 USA Indoor Championships. I had finally made a dream become a reality.

After the 2011 season I didn’t have the money to receive the proper training, treatment for recovery, and travel expenses to make it to high profile meets. I lacked equipment and good facilities to keep up the great times and record setting pace I was on the year before. I struggled for a year and also missed the 2012 Olympic team. That experience gave me the fuel to learn how to adapt to any situation in life. I now have a great coach, which coached the 2012 Olympic Gold Medalist in the Men's 400 hurdles, and a great track to train on at UCLA.

With your support I have faith that I will accomplish my goals of competing in the USA and World Track & Field Championships. I have no plans of coming home without a medal. Your donations/sponsorships will contribute to the expenses as followed:

  1. Travel (flight and lodging only) = $11,000
    1. Trip for international competition : ($2,000 / trip x 2 trips) = $4,000
    2. Trip within USA for competition : ($1,000 / trip x 7 trips) = $7,000
  2. Medical = $3,192
    1. Chiropractor / A.R.T : ($38 / visit x 24 visits) = $912
    2. Massage Therapist : ($20 / visit x 24 visits) = $480
    3. Sports physician / Physio : ($60 / visit x 5 visits) = $300
    4. Medical insurance (specific to athletes) : (unknown) = $1,500
  3. Gear = $1130
    1. Nike Zoom Ja Spikes : ($110 / pair x 3 pairs) = $330
    2. Nike Air Pegasus : ($100 / pair x 4 pairs) = $400
    3. Athletic clothing : (unknown) = $400
  4. Training = $360
    1. Running coaching : ($0 / coach x 1 coach) = $0
    2. 24 hour Fitness membership : ($30 / month x 12 months) = $360
  5. Total 2013 Running Expenses = $15,682

This is the total expense projection for the 2013 Indoor and Outdoor season, totaling in $15,682. The $6,000 I am seeking will get me through the first half of the season. I am confident that by the midpoint of the season I will be competing on a high enough level to get paid for my wins and hopefully get a contract with a large sponsorship. All I need is the help to jump start my season and my performance will propel me through the rest of the year and a Championship.

Please remember to visit my website, jameshowellusa.com, to keep up with my schedule, results, news, and other things going on in the life of James Howell. The site also provides you with my past accomplishments, records, multimedia, and a more in depth biography.

I know that not everyone will be able to contribute or donate a large amount of money. I would truly appreciate any help you can provide; whether it is $1, or just letting someone know about my story and dream. I will be utilizing Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, and Socialcam, as well as the share tool on Indiegogo.com. It would be a blessing if you could do the same. Please help me spread the word. Tell everyone, who might be able to or want to help, know about my Indiegogo campaign and let’s turn this dream into a reality!

Thank you for your time and God bless...

story:
“In order to change, people need to become aware of their sensations and the way that their bodies interact with the world around them. Physical self-awareness is the first step in releasing the tyranny of the past.” 
― Bessel A. van der Kolk, The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind, and Body in the Healing of Trauma

I am a Special Education Teacher and avid yoga practitioner in St. Louis who has taught and volunteered in under served neighborhoods and schools in Kansas City and St. Louis, MO. I have worked as an in home parent educator and classroom teacher with the The Children's Center for the Visually Impaired and The Delta Gamma Center for the Visually Impaired and Special School District of St. Louis County. In my time in the classroom and working in the homes of people living in poverty, I have witnessed and heard stories of the mental and emotional impact living in poverty has on the health and well being of families and my students. 

As an individual who has accessed the healing properties of yoga to overcome my own struggles with trauma, I have always wanted to be able to teach these skills to my students and families in a ways that are meaningful and accessible to them so they can begin to feel good in their bodies and begin to feel whole, even if it is only for a few seconds in a yoga class or while taking a break in a one-on-one trauma senstive yoga therapy session in their school day or in an after school program.

In September, I will be attending a 3 Day Trauma Senstive Yoga Teacher Certification Program in Chicago, Illinois through an organization called Street Yoga, which is a not for profit out of Seattle, WA whose aim is to teach trauma sensitive yoga practices to educators to better serve  students in ways that will truly impact their entire life.

Here is the breakdown of the cost for the certification:

$290 goes towards the registration for the Street Yoga Trauma Sensitive Yoga Certification 

$310 goes towards the airfare I will need to fly to Chicago for the weekend

story:
Join the runLOVED Movement

We're runners. Not great ones. We're more like those runners who realize how challenging, nerve-wracking, and even lonely a race can sometimes be. The cheers and high fives from the crowd along the course are nice, but what we really need is the support of friends and family.

And that's why Motigo was born. During the Phoenix Marathon we realized we could create something that uses everyday technology (a smartphone!) to allow familiar voices to provide encouragement, assurance and support, but without interfering with the run. 

Motigo is an iPhone app* that allows runners to hear pre-recorded, personalized audio messages from friends and family, for an emotional boost when they need it most (that's race day for now)! 

Based on the feedback we've received from 1000+ early users, and the enthusiasm expressed by races, brands and causes, we know we are on the right track. By supporting this campaign, you will give us the continued momentum to bring smiles, laughs, goosebumps and even tears to runners by allowing their biggest fans to be with them, every step of the way. There to inspire, cheer, and celebrate their amazing accomplishments - whether its a 5K or Ultra Marathon, or everything in between. 

*iPhone only as of January 2015. Android coming in early 2015!

How it Works

Motigo is focused on race day! We like to think of it as a milestone event, one worthy of having your friends and family alongside you.

During the race, runners move along listening to their music and periodically the music fades to the background. Brief audio messages from friends and/or family are then automatically played at various pre-selected mile markers along the course, then the music resumes playing at its previous volume. 

Way better than intrusive phone calls, the buzzing of texts, and generic likes and cheers!  


What We Need & What You Get

The more we can successfully raise, the more cool things we can build and do (faster), and the more talented people we can add to the team! 
However, for us, one of the most exciting parts of having you on board is that you get to experience Motigo, and the perks we've crafted to help motivate and inspire you (see perks sidebar). Above and beyond the benefits of enhancing your race day forever, and some sweet gear, we're excited to provide some amazing and exclusive running experiences. We want to do everything we can to get you out running and enjoying your races!


New Perk #2! The What Moves You?  


Our Journey

2014 has been an exciting year of learning, building, and testing. We've been focused on engaging with runners at events both big and small including the Chicago Marathon, the Denver Rock n' Roll Marathon and the St. Jude Marathon. This is only the start towards building a lasting brand. 

The Real Impact - The People We Can Touch

Having just partnered with St. Jude in early December, we had a first hand opportunity to both see the hospital and spend time talking with so many of their admirable Heroes (runners who have raised money). 

One of our goals is to work closely to help the millions of passionate runners, walkers and even cyclists who are participating in races to raise money for the charities they care deeply about. They are directly impacting the lives and well being of others, and we're determined to support them in these efforts and help raise even more money for so many good causes.



Risks & Challenges

Awareness is our biggest challenge. If we're unable to fund marketing programs that educate and inform enough runners about the benefits of Motigo, that would be a risk to our future success. 

Development is another key area for us. This means continually enhancing the product and the experience, so that it delights all of our users and allows us to stay a step ahead as technology rapidly evolves. 

Lastly, we're excited to be patent pending. We have big ideas for running and beyond, but there is always risk in how or if our patent is granted.

All of the above are challenges, not obstacles. Our passion is to make a difference with a fun, inspiring, emotion evoking brand and the people we surround ourselves with will help us stay focused and execute! We are building a great team, and have world-class advisors and the support of some very well respected folks in the running community. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if contributing just isn't for you. So here are some other ideas...

  • Nearly 50 million people regularly run in the US and there are nearly 20 million race finishers. Find one (or many) and share this with them! 
  • Like us on Facebook. Follow us on Twitter. Blog about us. Every little bit is sincerely appreciated.

We Owe Some Major Thanks...

We didn't get here alone, and won't succeed without the talented folks around us. Thanks to Ryan Linstrom and Ben Orsborne at Land & Sea for creative, Ryan Tong for our website, our good friend Jeff Werthammer (and his wife Kaley, our actress),  Justin Torrey - kid talent and future superstar, Alicia Benjamin our social media guru, and Kieran McCarthy & Jeff Schell our counsels, And thanks to those trusted executives advising us including Doug Galen, Ellen Kramer, Lonnie Somers, Gary Stone, and Todd Siegel.  There are probably some of you we momentarily forgot about ...please remind us so we can properly recognize all that you've done thus far.
story_txt:
Join the runLOVED Movement
 We're runners. Not great ones. We're more like those runners who realize how challenging, nerve-wracking, and even lonely a race can sometimes be. The cheers and high fives from the crowd along the course are nice, but what we really need is the support of friends and family.
And that's why Motigo was born. During the Phoenix Marathon we realized we could create something that uses everyday technology (a smartphone!) to allow familiar voices to provide encouragement, assurance and support, but without interfering with the run. 
Motigo is an iPhone app* that allows runners to hear pre-recorded, personalized audio messages from friends and family, for an emotional boost when they need it most (that's race day for now)! 

Based on the feedback we've received from 1000+ early users, and the enthusiasm expressed by races, brands and causes, we know we are on the right track. By supporting this campaign, you will give us the continued momentum to bring smiles, laughs, goosebumps and even tears to runners by allowing their biggest fans to be with them, every step of the way. There to inspire, cheer, and celebrate their amazing accomplishments - whether its a 5K or Ultra Marathon, or everything in between. 
*iPhone only as of January 2015. Android coming in early 2015!

How it Works
Motigo is focused on race day! We like to think of it as a milestone event, one worthy of having your friends and family alongside you.

During the race, runners move along listening to their music and periodically the music fades to the background. Brief audio messages from friends and/or family are then automatically played at various pre-selected mile markers along the course, then the music resumes playing at its previous volume. 

Way better than intrusive phone calls, the buzzing of texts, and generic likes and cheers!  





 What We Need & What You Get

The more we can successfully raise, the more cool things we can build and do (faster), and the more talented people we can add to the team! 
However, for us, one of the most exciting parts of having you on board is that you get to experience Motigo, and the perks we've crafted to help motivate and inspire you (see perks sidebar). Above and beyond the benefits of enhancing your race day forever, and some sweet gear, we're excited to provide some amazing and exclusive running experiences. We want to do everything we can to get you out running and enjoying your races!




New Perk #2! The What Moves You?  





Our Journey 2014 has been an exciting year of learning, building, and testing. We've been focused on engaging with runners at events both big and small including the Chicago Marathon, the Denver Rock n' Roll Marathon and the St. Jude Marathon. This is only the start towards building a lasting brand. 



The Real Impact - The People We Can Touch
Having just partnered with St. Jude in early December, we had a first hand opportunity to both see the hospital and spend time talking with so many of their admirable Heroes (runners who have raised money). 
One of our goals is to work closely to help the millions of passionate runners, walkers and even cyclists who are participating in races to raise money for the charities they care deeply about. They are directly impacting the lives and well being of others, and we're determined to support them in these efforts and help raise even more money for so many good causes.






Risks & Challenges Awareness is our biggest challenge. If we're unable to fund marketing programs that educate and inform enough runners about the benefits of Motigo, that would be a risk to our future success. 
Development is another key area for us. This means continually enhancing the product and the experience, so that it delights all of our users and allows us to stay a step ahead as technology rapidly evolves. 
Lastly, we're excited to be patent pending. We have big ideas for running and beyond, but there is always risk in how or if our patent is granted.
All of the above are challenges, not obstacles. Our passion is to make a difference with a fun, inspiring, emotion evoking brand and the people we surround ourselves with will help us stay focused and execute! We are building a great team, and have world-class advisors and the support of some very well respected folks in the running community. 
   Other Ways You Can Help We understand if contributing just isn't for you. So here are some other ideas...  Nearly 50 million people regularly run in the US and there are nearly 20 million race finishers. Find one (or many) and share this with them! 
 Like us on Facebook. Follow us on Twitter. Blog about us. Every little bit is sincerely appreciated. 
  
We Owe Some Major Thanks...We didn't get here alone, and won't succeed without the talented folks around us. Thanks to Ryan Linstrom and Ben Orsborne at Land & Sea for creative, Ryan Tong for our website, our good friend Jeff Werthammer (and his wife Kaley, our actress),  Justin Torrey - kid talent and future superstar, Alicia Benjamin our social media guru, and Kieran McCarthy & Jeff Schell our counsels, And thanks to those trusted executives advising us including Doug Galen, Ellen Kramer, Lonnie Somers, Gary Stone, and Todd Siegel.  There are probably some of you we momentarily forgot about ...please remind us so we can properly recognize all that you've done thus far.

story:
BREAKING NEWS!!  Nothing less than a miracle has occurred here. Dr. Gupta, the same Dr. who just 24 hours ago was worried about how complicated the fractures were , phoned to say that there has been a big change and they feel they will now not have to operate!!!  They will set them in normal plaster and hope for the best..Yes, unbelievable!! This can only be the amazing power of all the prayers AND LOVE that were offered up around the world..!!! What a wonderful gift to bring in the New Year in tremendous gratitude and remembrance that far greater powers are watching over us all...HAPPY NEW YEAR TO YOU ALL!! May the shower of blessings continue to light your paths..

            A tree fell on Kiran and her family killing her little brother, Raj, in front of her and badly breaking her leg, shoulder, and arm. Dr. said she needed to have at least 3 surgeries , maybe 4, since there was serious nerve damage in her arm as well.

 Kiran's father drank himself to death leaving her brother and sister alone with her mom. The relatives took away all their ancestral land leaving them to live in a tiny hovel nearly starving till we found them. For past 8 years they have been walking  2 hours a day from the top of a steep mtn to come to study and eat lunch here in Ramana's Garden . www.sayyesnow.org

 Kiran is a bright, dedicated, talented little girl and really deserves all the help we can give her to see her through this back to health

 We are blessed to have one of the best Orthopedic surgeons in India that would have been doing the operations. He is well known to us as he has been putting all our little "Humpty Dumptys" back together again for past 23 years.

 We ONLY need  hospitalization at a cost of $30 a day not including medicines and followup physical therapies...YEA!!!!

Your donations are greatly appreciated and are tax deductible.

story:
1,000 Youth on Course kids will play golf in December.
Every $5 donation gives one round.

Our Goal for Giving Tuesday is $5,000 or 1,000 rounds.

You’re passionate about the game of golf and so is SCGA Youth on Course.  The game teaches character, decision making, and healthy living, which is why we continue to make it more affordable for all SoCal youth. Today, share that passion with the next generation of golfers by sponsoring a Youth on Course member’s round of golf.

story:
Summary

My name is Rupert, I am completely dependant  on a motorized wheelchair for all my mobility needs as I was born with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy( a severe muscle wasting disease). My parents were told I wouldn't live past 16, I am currently 31. My Mother who I lived with most of my life was my full time caregiver and suffers from Multiple Sclerosis. I realized It was time to let my mother retire as she is getting older and her MS is catching up to her. I moved out with Steven and Allen. We are renting a nice manufactured home in a quiet nieghborhood.  The wheelchair ramp we are currently using is extremely temporary as it is very steep and not 100% safe. It takes two people to guide me down the ramp "safely". We need a safe ramp that can be used independently and at will. This Ramp would allow me to access the outdoors and the rest of the cummunity much safer and more easily. This will significantly enrich the quality of my life and make me a happier person overall. 

What We Need

We need to raise $5,000.  This will go toward all needed building materials (2x4's, 2x6's, 4x4's, plywood, lattice, screws, nails, etc), needed tools, and labor costs.  No matter what the amount actually raised is, the money will still be used toward construction of the ramp.  The new ramp will be straight and at least 25 feet long with railings and non-skid strips. As we don't have a ton of money, there isn't much we can offer in return, except for our eternal undying gratitude.  We can, give a shout out to everyone who pitches in (on facebook).  Photos and video updates of the progress will be posted online as well.

story:
OPERATION HAWKEYE: K920 

John Douangdara & Bart  – U.S. Special Ops Heroes 

We owe our freedom to warriors in our armed forces who protect us day and night, at home an around the globe.  We remember with special gratitude those who sacrificed their lives in service to our nation, including the Special Operations forces (SOF) heroes killed on August 6, 2011 when the Taliban shot down their CH-47 Chinook helicopter, call sign EXTORTION 17, on a distant battlefield in Afghanistan. Thirty one American warriors died that day, including SOF K9 handler, U.S. Navy Petty Officer 1st Class  John Douangdara, and Bart, a SOF K9, pictured below with Kevin Houston, a Navy SEAL who also fell during the EXTORTION 17 shootdown.



OPERATION HAWKEYE 

Immediately after the EXTORTION 17 shootdown, Virginia schoolboy Will Thomas (shown in the Sports Illustrated feature below) launched a grassroots mission called OPERATION HAWKEYE (OHe), using sport to honor the sacrifices of John Douangdara, Bart, and other fallen SOF warriors and their families.  The team is made up of tens of thousands of individuals, businesses, non-profit organizations, athletes and coaches, and media figures and writers from across America ― working together to make a difference in support of the SOF community.  OHe is a team effort that assists major nonprofits serving every branch of SOF, with all donations from mission operations applied by professionals positioned to aid the families of the fallen and honor the sacrifices of SOF warriors and their loved ones.  For further details, see http://www.ophawkeye.com. 



SOF K9 Memorial Foundation

The SOF K9 Memorial Foundation is a small group of military and civilian K9 professionals dedicated to honoring SOF K9s lost since 9/11.  The Foundation dedicated a memorial statue at the Airborne and Special Operations Museum in Fayetteville, North Carolina in 2013, and is continuing to enhance the memorial working closely with the Museum and the U.S. Army.  For further details, see http://www.sofk9memorial.com.

Red Circle Foundation

The Red Circle Foundation, established in 2012 by former U.S. Navy SEAL Brandon Webb, is a "quick reaction" non-profit providing funding assistance for Special Operations families in need and other worthy endeavors honoring the fallen and supporting the SOF Gold Star community.  For further details, see http://redcirclefoundation.org.

K920: Honoring Fallen SOF K9s & K9 Handlers  

K920 is a three-part operation in honor of John Douangdara and Bart to: (i) elevate public awareness about the sacrifices of SOF K-9s and their handlers, and (ii) raise funds for enhancements to the SOF K9 Memorial at the Airborne & Special Operations Museum in Fayetteville, North Carolina and the John Douangdara Memorial War Dog Park in South Sioux City, Nebraska.

Part I: Pledge Drive

The first element of K920 calls for OHe mission teammates to secure $20K in donation pledges,  Individuals are asked to pledge donations of $20 or more 

Enterprises are asked to pledge donations of $200 or more, with recognition across all OpHawkeye online platforms.

Part II: The Shooting Challenge

There are 38 U.S. college and professional basketball teams with canine mascots.  K920 would give OHe sharpshooter Will Thomas a single day to make 20% of the total number of 3-point baskets made by these teams during the entire 2013-2014 season: 1,599.    He will undertake this challenge the week of National Dog Day, August 26, 2014, in honor of John, Bart, and other SOF K9 heroes.

Part III: Allocation

ALL donations will fund enhancements to the SOF K9 Memorial at the Airborne & Special Operations Museum in North Carolina and the John Douangdara Memorial War Dog Park in Nebraska, working with the Red Circle Foundation, SOF K9 Memorial Foundation, Airborne & Special Operations Museum Foundation, and other relevant stakeholders.

story: I want to open up a shop to sell pasties and povitica and give a percentage of what I make to cancer research. My mother passed away from cancer. And I want to help in any way to further the research for a cure. Pasties and Pova were two of our traditional family favorites. I want to share this amazing food with the world and help it to become a better place by funding cancer research.

story:
On December 7th, 2011 our daughter Madison was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes, at just 5 years old. Her diagnosis has affected our family deeply. Our pain and grief of the loss of her freedom as a child has inspired us to raise awareness about a growing epidemic affecting young child all over.  In order to help our family and other families cope and have a place to reach out for support we have decided to become proactive with our daughter's disease. Young children diagnosed with this disease are subject to 10 to 12 finger pokes a day and as many as 3 to 8 insulin shots a day to maintain their health. Diabetes is not just a strain on these children but also on their siblings, parents and caregivers. The goal of "But I Have Diabetes"TM is to lend support, caring and understanding to all families newly diagnosed and those who still years after diagnosis are still feeling the strain of the journey that living with type 1 diabetes is. 

We have created a non-profit www.butihavediabetes.org and have become very active in the persute of trying to make supplies for children with T1D accessable to them and their families. We are hosting a poker run this July to raise funds to help Maddie and children like her pumps and any other supplies that they might need taht insurance won't cover. 

These children just want a chance to live a normal healthy life just like everyone else. They should be given the same opportunities. 

Through www.butihavediabetes.org we are hoping create a place for parents to reach out to for support. There aren't enough resources for newly diagnosed families. We are trying to change that, one step at a time. 

We are hoping to raise at least $1,000 to help get children much needed insulin pumps. We will be donating all our proceeds to families who are unable to provide needed pump and or supplies for their children due to insurance restrictions. If we do not reach our goal of $1,000 we will stll be donating our proceeds to our cause but will keep holding fundraisers until we succeed to do our part get children in need supplies they need to stay healthy. 

If you are unable to to donate a monitary gift you can still help! Share this link to your facebook, twitter, blog, or even just mention this campaign to someone you know!

story:
Beloved Cyclist "Chuey" Munkanta Beaten Unconscious and Arrested By Police

 article pulled from The Uptown Almanac

Kachusha "Chuey" Munkanta is one of the most beloved figures in the San Francisco cycling community.  He's known internationally for his hand-made cycling caps, made and sold right here in the Mission.  And everyone, from MASH to PD Bird, know him to be a "peaceful" and "non-violent" person.  He even delivers coffee, by bike, for De La Paz Coffee Roasters--a company undeniably of peace.

So it's with great shock and disgust that we learn of his arrest and police beating while trying to monitor SFPD's treatment of Latinos.  A close friend of his forwarded along his story:

Thursday night/ Friday morning Chuey stopped on the side of the street in the Mission when he saw the cops having 4 Latinos lined up against a gate. He stopped to make sure the youth were being fairly treated.

The cops then asked him to cross the street, when Chuey said he couldn't observe from across the street. They (2-3 cops) jumped him as he was hugging his bike. They wrestled him to the ground then continued to push him into the ground, twisting his arm, slamming his head into the ground. He was in jail for almost 24 hours and released after his family paid bail. They charged him with 3 felonies for assaulting 3 cops with enough force to cause grave bodily harm and  2 misdemeanors for resisting arrest.

Chuey was released on $150,000 bail and arraigned yesterday afternoon at the Superior Court of California, where he was issued a public defender.  Chuey is also faced with steep medical costs after having to visit the ER for his injuries, where doctors advised him to have a cat scan.

In addition to this fundraising campaign, you can get his caps online at Mission Bicycle or MASH (who will donate all proceeds to his defense), or in person at Box Dog Bikes or Pushbike.
